reviews.review_text: Hard as balls, fantastic music, great gameplay, and a great premise in the story. It also has the side benefit of being completely unique, nothing else like it out there at the moment.  A game I keep cursing at, rage quiting, and yet keep coming back to. Truly rewarding, as the game gets better as you get better.  Can't recommend it enough.

Keep in mind that I've been dreaming of a proper top-down rhythm game for years. Quite a lot of what I have to say is based on the fact that I think with a bit of work this game could have potentially been my favorite game of all time.  It's excellent concept, straight-to-the-point presentation, great use of color, more than functional randomization, a very nice shrine mechanic, the ability to dig through walls, fully functional and easy to to understand beat counter, some interesting boss fights, speed/scorerun support and a huge number of different ways to play the game all do a very good job of distracting the player from realizing that the core rhythm/roguelike concept is actually used in quite a uniform and unimaginative way.  The way the game works is that you have a beat counter that multiplies your gold the more you move and attack in accordance with the beat. This is a really interesting mechanic and doesn't require any outside knowledge or athleticism to get good with (like some dancepad games do) but it's actual implementation leaves me thinking it was not realized properly.   First off, the only punishment that you get for missing a beat with Cadence (the standard character) is that you cannot move for about a half-second and you lose your gold multiplier. This is ok, I suppose (certainly instant death on missed beat would be far too cruel, though there's a character for exactly that purpose) but it doesn't really hinder you in anyway. The most blatant example of how little the beat mechanic matters are the Blademaster enemies in Zone 4, which parry your attacks on reaction and then lunge forward, then becoming vulnerable. If you are constantly moving along with the beat these 'range-proof' enemies can group up with time and become a real nuisance, but if you stand still killing them is almost effortless. You can bait out their parry, step backward, and then strike immediately to kill them. Of course, you can do this along with the beat if your footing is good enough, but doing it without beat sync completely removes any risk in this case.The amount of enemies and gold in Zone 4 is excessive, to say the least, so even if you were to walk around with a gold multiplier of 1.0 you would have more than enough gold for the shops.  Second, absolutely none of the levels seem to have been designed with the rhythm mechanic in mind, behind the simple concept of allowing the player to dig through walls if they get trapped behind a wall. All four zones are fairly entertaining, but really, none of them would be out of place in a pure roguelike. The source of difficulty in all four zones comes not from keeping the beat or engaging a 'dance routine' with specific enemy, but something totally irrelevant to rhythm. Zone 1 is difficult because the areas are cramped, Zone 2 is difficult because the areas are too wide open and the enemies are nimble, Zone 3 is difficult because of the ice/fire hazards, Zone 4 is difficult because it forces the player to edge along walls which are full of traps. Zone 4 is the only zone where I would actually say the player is free to engage in rythmic pattern without beng forced to go along a very distinct path, which is overshadowed by the zone's overwhelming number of brutal enemies and traps.  Lastly--and this is runnng FAR against the grain here, I have not found a single person besides me that has this opinion: the music isn't actually that good. As far as it's intended purpose goes, anyway. Surpisingly, few of the tracks are particularly fast or even energetic. This leads to a lot of levels where, if you even care about the beat at all, you are stuck moving at a clumsy and slow rate. There is only one track in the game that has players move more than once per beat, and only one track in the game which has rests--both of which are the same track, King Konga. King Konga is by far the best boss in the game because he is not only the only boss which has irregular rhythm elements, but the only boss where your accordance with the rhythm actually matters. Death Metal has one of the fastest tracks in the game but it ends up being practically meaningless because the boss is so easy you could beat him without stepping in time even once.  All in all this is quite a fun game but not really the ultimate rhythm/action hybrid I've been waiting for. Ironically the people I would reccomend this game most to are people that have don't have much interest in roguelikes or rhythm games, but like the 'idea' of both. If there's some sort of update to the degree of randomization I think the game would be a tremendous platform for fangames--without actually touching the level editor, I actually think I could make levels far more interesting than some of the less fortunate randomizations I've seen. Some sort of compilation of levels made by hundreds of modders would be excellent.

I'm so excited to finally be able to review this game post-launch!  I pre-ordered Crypt of the NecroDancer back in 2013 when they started allowing people to do so, and I've been playing the alpha since it became available in April of 2014.  It's a rhythm-based roguelike with some small measure of cross-play achievements (you unlock things as you progress in the game for future playthroughs in other modes), and while all items start identified (i.e., you always know what a scroll or weapon is, unlike a 'true' roguelike), their placements and whether or not they even show up is randomized.  The dungeon randomization is great, and you can specify specific seeds if you want to share levels with other players or work on one specific layout, but where the game really shines -- and its purpose, really -- is the music.  You can only move, attack, use items, cast spells, and anything else *on the beat*. Monsters also move on the beat, and they move in routinely predictable patterns so that over time you learn how to anticipate them and counter them, and in fact some monsters require you to learn these patterns and match the beat in order to even damage them. The skill cap is pretty high, the amount of replayability is immense (there are 9 playable characters and a 10th 'challenge' character, all of whom greatly alter the gameplay in different and interesting ways), and there's even a 'beatless' character that allows you to play the game like a traditional roguelike (monsters move when you do, and you're not forced to stick to the rhythm). And if you want a real challenge, you can even play on a dancepad...  As someone who has been playing roguelikes ever since actually growing up playing Rogue, and who used to religiously follow rec.games.roguelike, I am so delighted to see an injection of 'newness' into the genre like NecroDancer. It's sorely needed, and while I doubt we'll ever see it emulated, I hope it inspires another developer to merge *their* love of two genres into something as incredibly engaging, challenging, and outright *fun* as this.   I am so happy for Brace Yourself Games, and I'm so incredibly excited that this game has finally surfaced for others to experience and play. It's VERY good.

This is the most impressive rogue-like I have ever played. CoND beautifully integrates tile based combat with music. Each turn lasts for a beat of the current level's song, leading to fun, fast paced action. Even during early access it felt like a complete game, and the full release is a masterpiece.  The controls are easy and straighforward, requiring only the arrow keys to play. The graphics are simple but well made.   The music is great. The soundtrack was composed by Danny B, and each song is edited masterfully into the game. CoND lets you use your own music for the levels, but I have never done it because I love the core soundtrack so much. Despite hearing the songs hundreds of times, I never get tired of them.  The various weapons and equipment provide a wide variety of play styles and item interactions. The enemies are well designed, each with varying movement and attack mechanics. The boss fights are unique and wonderful experiences. Each one is musically themed, and the varying musical styles reinforces the awesomeness of the game's music.  There is a very large amount of content and replayability. Between items, enemies, and floor layouts, there is a lot of variation between runs. There are high score and fastest time leaderboards which are very competitive, and people frequently race the game live. CoND can be very difficult at first because you have to learn each weapon's mechanics and each enemy's attack patterns, but there are many tutorial and training mechanisms built into the game. Practicing is well worth the time, and mastering the game is very rewarding.  I recommend this game to anyone. It is an absolute must play if you like rogue-likes or music based games.

[Minor spoilers about end game gameplay].  I had been in the Crypt for almost 20 hours before I first encountered the Necrodancer. I'd like to talk of that experience:  The identity of the Dead Ringer revealed, I felt a pang of confusion, only to hear him guide me, and then to realize I had to juggle two heroes terrified me. How many runs had I failed this far? And another boss after what already seemed like an impossible ordeal.   It only took me a few moments to realize the new mechanic I had to juggle in the last fight, and it was an amazing surprise which immediately filled the dancer floor with new energy.   I spent the first minute of the encounter with the Necrodancer keeping my heroes side by side, getting used to the beat. The easy beginning really affords those fighting Necrodancer for the first time the time they need to get ready.   And then, one by one I begin aligning my heroes, triggering bombs to the stage--not too difficult.   When the Necrodancer took to the dance floor, indeed was my heart beating at the 120bpm step, in sync with the Necrodancer himself. I begrudgingly set aside my Obsidian Crossbow and equipped the Golden Lute, determined to do this right. At first, I ran from his reanimated fiends and explosive spells, trying to realign myself and regroup with my ally, but as soon as I understood his rhythm I slided in for a hit. The Necrodancer skips away only losing a single heart from my note, summoning more monsters between us.  Black Knights began to flank me on all sides and it's a challenge to keep them off with my ally's Flail. At one point I realize the Golden Lute can only sing its music if Cadence has a empty tile to move to, so being surrounded by shield bearing skeletons on two sides and a wall and ally covering the other two, I struggle to make any movements at all, all while rapidly losing health. For an instant I fear the worst, but in the next beat does my ally bash his Flail fowards, knocking back one skeleton--I immediately pounce on the next beat, allowing my Lute to sound the minions to dust.   The fight continues with me piercing again and again with my Lute, bringing the Necrodancer to a third of his health, while monsters continue to scratch my ally and I. In the fight I've lost four of my nine hearts, leaving both my ally and I at one and a half hearts left, and as I continue to hit the Necrodancer do increasingly powerful monsters seem to appear.  Eventually, there are too many skeletons in erratic formations I can't easily line up to attack, their pursuit herding me to one side of the dance floor where an Ogre has just joined. I've died many times to Ogres in the fourth zone, but I know the brute, slow, can be defeated if I merely kite around it. However, I worry that in the process, the new ally by my side would then get smashed in the ensuing blow. I move in, hitting him again and again as I circle to his back.  It was at that time, checking the hearts of my ally and I, going over the directional combinations to use bombs, switching to my holstered weapon or beating my war drum, as well as predicting the path of the many dancers of the Necrodancer did I make my fatal error. My attention split, I panic and move one tile away from the Ogre, immediately attracting his singularly directed club.   My obsidian armor, then powered down and thin as paper from the onslaught of reanimations is cleaved in two, Cadence immediately perishing under the mighty blow.   I will now begin talking about my opinion of the game:  I spent 20 hours trying to get farther and farther than before.   Being able to dance with the Necrodancer was an incredible experience, despite dying, my body is still flowing with music high. Please try this game. There are very smart design choices evident throughout every aspect. The music, the level design, the enemies and items all progress so well. Timing each act to the length of a song, having enemies which all have simple but broad ranges of dance moves to overcome make them easy to approach but brilliantly challenging in hoards. You feel extremely rewarded for your experienced-earned dexterity the roguelike demands--the game is a fantastic challenge that's never too easy.   A great example is in certain circumstances (secret vendors and trapdoors) do you find yourself in an incredibly confined space with two minibossess and two small minions. The first time you see this your fear and greenness lead to your immediate demise, but after enough of dancing do you begin to, not only feel comfortable with these, but even actively seek them out for the item and gold reward from defeating them.   Once you can beat bosses, your greed begins to demand you defeat them without a single misstep, for the glorious Flawless Victory that rewards your ego as well as giving you an additional chest to bolster your hero. I thought being an indie game this would be a quick fun change of pace but it's so much more. I've only played twenty hours but I don't intend to stop any time soon. It's a game I would recommend to any friend who comes over, it's a game I would play when I have a short break or if I have a few hours. Sometimes it can be tough if you keep dying but the rewards essentially beg you to succeed. I keep coming back for more Crypt of the Necrodancer!

In the age of depressing, gritty, gaming-realism, this game is ridiculously fun and quirky, and I hope the creators know what a gem of a game they've got here. And the music? I don't even know where to start. I only wish there was more of this boogie based dungeoncrawler...  Did I mention lots of female protagonists?

This game combines rhythm and roguelike like fried chicken and waffles. If you haven't experienced them together, you think it's a bizarre combo that won't mesh well. Then you try it and you wonder why you haven't had the two together before. Where has this magical combo been your entire life?  Gimmick aside, the game is still beautifully designed. The enemies all have tells and literally have choreographed attacks. Everything gives signs before the action takes place, much like many roguelikes. It's just that this game took that dance and set it to a kickin' soundtrack. You can even practice against enemies without needing to throw yourself into the deep end to figure out their tells.  Even the characters are more upbeat and lively than your average roguelike. The little things, like how they greet NPCs (shyly VS boldly VS force of habit) and their surprised reactions to teleportation make them seem less like digital avatars and more like humans. A little detail that adds a lot of magic to the game.  [edit] THE STORY. Add the story to another fantastic bit of this game. Only frustrating bit is how hard it is to complete story mode, but hey, it's a roguelike. That's to be expected from the genre.  TL;DR - A wonderfully charming game that blends two very different genres in a lovingly-designed piece. I strongly recommend you pick up the game and the soundtrack!

Both challenging for experianced players while not offputting for those who are new to the genre, and with a diverse range of control options, from traditional inputs to DDR pads, it has a lot to offer anyone who is willing to give it a shot.

Crypt of the Necrodancer has very good art direction, an amazing soundtrack and a stunning and innovative new mechanism, which forces you to dance through the dungeon to the beat of the soundtrack.  I think the game concept is brilliant and really well executed. The soundtrack is worth buying on its own.  However, I did not enjoy the game for much more than an hour. I pretty much have a non-existing feeling for rhythm and as such, the game was quite frustrating for me, as I was not able to make any progress.  There is a character available from the start to redemy this, which does not require dancing to the soundtrack, but without it this central mechanism there are many more dungeon crawlers suited for that kind of playstyle.   Verdict: Awesome, if you have rhythm, mediocre if you have none!

Easily one of the best rhythm games to come out EVER. CoTND is a procedurally generated dungeon crawler with the difficulty and addictiveness of Binding of Isaac, with, imo, a killer soundtrack. This is probably because the music was made by the same guy but, I digress.   And if for some reason you hate the music (or you get sick of dying and hearing the same bloody song from level 1 over and over again like I do (inb4 'git good')) you can substitute the level songs with your own music.   You play at Cadence, one of several musically-named individuals who must make their way through the titular Crypt for their each individual reasons, which is fun but the true awesomeness lies in the music-related combat and sweet pixel art visuals. That being said the game is hard. It's really hard. The good news is with a few proper upgrades you can become veritably unstoppable in any of the worlds. The learning curve drops into a cliff about the time you meet the Red Dragon, who can take you out with a single well-timed fire breath from across the map, and he'll show up every now and again in Zone 1.  Easy to learn and hard to master are how I would describe this game, and would definitely recommend it unless you're known to break things if you get easily frustrated. Mice and keyboards are expensive.

This is one of the only Early Access games that I have purchased very early on. It also happens to be the first early access that I have absolutely loved from the beginning and it's probably one of the only early access games that I purchased that actually came out as a complete game.  Crypt of the Necrodancer immediately caught my eye because of its unique gameplay (or was it just an impulse buy because of the pun?). It's essentially a Rythm Roguelike game. It has most of the elements of a Rogue-like, except you have to stay on beat!  The soundtrack is absolutely amazing (and now offered in 3 different variations!) and the game is deceivingly difficult. It's very easy to pick up, very hard to master and highly addictive.  Even having played through the first 3 zones countless time while I waited for the fourth one to come out, then all four a bunch of times when it did, I still enjoy playing this game from time to time (I have played a lot more than Steam indicates.)  I often despise randomly generated levels but in this game it works very well and follow a set of logical rules. Each level will always be similar while always offering something new. There are tons of different items that will help you on your runs and different characters that provide different challenges when you get bored of Cadence, the main character.   A very charming and challenging game with a lot of replayability, fully worth the 16.99$.

Now that I have tried the game I say I agree. NecroDancer is two parts rougelike one part dungeon crawler with a sprinkle of beat matching game sprinkled in. Every action throughout Necrodancer is done to the beat of each levels song. You try to move down floors through the dungeons while collecting loot, fighting monsters and just generally trying not to die to some sort of nasty trap.  I feel like Crypt of the NecroDancer is a well rounded challenging game and I recommend it to any rougelike fans.

The enemies all move differently, and attack differently, and can range from your generic skeleton or slime, to a green zombie-like clone of yourself, that copies your moves backwards. TL;DR: 9/10. They did almost everything right. Mostly boils down to how experienced you're willing to get, because it's tricky to get used to.  Crypt of the NecroDancer is about shanking monsters to a kickass beat. The game stars a girl named Cadence whose entire character, backstory and development can be summarised by 'a girl named Cadence'. It is very much centered around the gameplay and music working together, which works super well in a pretty flexible way compared to other rhythm-based games. The introduction is short and doesn't add much to the game other than justifying the mechanics, so you'll pretty much have the same experience regardless.  The game takes 'turn-based' in a slightly different way. Each beat of the song is represented at the bottom of the screen and symbolises a turn each. If you miss a beat or do something you're not supposed to such as walk into a wall of stone, every enemy still gets a turn while you're standing there hoping nobody noticed that your pants just fell down. Each time you miss a beat, your current combo is broken, meaning you don't have any time to stop and read useful information as even standing still will bring it to a screeching halt. Combo, you say? Why yes indeed, a combo. Maintaining the combo gives a boost to the amount of gold you pick up. Items that you pick up such as weapons or rings may give additional boosts to people who haven't accidentally thrown their flimsy shovel into a solid wall or stood around stroking themselves for too long unless they're a Monk, who for whatever reason is allowed to stroke himself for as long as he likes, which pretty much defeats the entire premise of the game. Comparing two items is a pain, as stopping to read the item's description will cause you to lose your combo, meaning you have to do a god damn raindance around the item just to read the stats and figure out if it's going to increase your chance of winning by 0.3%.  The ENTIRE game can be controlled using only 4 buttons/keys, which is about as convenient as an enemy who you can't actually hit with default gear because it won't line up next to you. I'm looking at you, golden slime. Sure, it's an interesting mechanic, but its main flaw is replacing memorising which key to press with memorising which combination of the same keys to press. It does show appropriate key combinations beside relevant items, but stopping to read it in the middle of a room more undead than a haunted mass grave is usually not worth the time. Guessing which combination is hardly worth the risk; you may be trying to heal in the middle of battle and end up throwing your sword across the room.  Using your own (or someone else's) music instead of the original game's works pretty decently in terms of functionality, although the soundtrack is good enough that you wouldn't want to replace any of it in the first place.  Local multiplayer is an interesting feature, although playing it with a first-timer was akin to participating in a three-legged race with a monkey who has bricks for feet. Unless you're both relatively similarly experienced, one of you is going to drag the other behind. Well I wouldn't say drag behind as much as them stumbling about while you're already buying everything from the shop with a stack of gold, which for this game was about as fun as letting a monkey with bricks for feet kick you in the shins after you finished the race without him, because now neither of you are having much fun at all. And that was after they went through incredibly short tutorial. Sure, it taught the basics, but you only really got to do everything in the tutorial once before it was over and it was clear that it didn't adequately equip a person with the experience they needed to survive unsupervised inside a padded room. If someone wants to play for the first time on your copy of the game, let them play singeplayer first.  Overall decent game. Can't say much about price because I almost exclusively buy games when they're on sale.

Part rhythm game, part dungeon crawler, Crypt of the NecroDancer is a well-excuted and original concept that marries its inspirations effectively without sacrificing too much from either genre. While it doesn't dig too deep into either genre's traits, if you enjoy rhythm games or dungeon crawlers you will find something to like here (if you can look past its flaws).  The meat of the gameplay revolves around spelunking through four zones of four stages each, with the first three having a small pool of possible bosses at the end. By keeping with the rhythm of the track and timing your actions to the beat, you are rewarded with a multiplier bonus that increases your gold pickups (and which later on enhances some equipment). While this is very important exploring the first two zones (especially as a new player because your loot pool will be low), zone 3 becomes extremely hectic with very aggressive monsters, lots of damage traps, and higher base gold pickups. The coin multiplier is useless except for gear once you reach Zone 4 because the gold pickups are so large that you can ignore it completely outside of combat. This seems to go against the design decision of adding rhythm elements and makes the game feel more like a barebones mobile-esque experience instead of DDR with swords. This might change with other characters (of which there are 10 to choose from), but the zones felt very similar in terms of game design when playing with Melody and Cadence for me.  Even though the game only has 16 (randomized) floors, you have a great deal of customization options from the level select hub. Different characters completely change how the game plays; a monk who dies from touching gold, a bard who ignores the rhythm and turns the game into a turn-based crawler, and a miner with infinite kickable bombs are some examples of how the gameplay can be radically modified. CotN is also completely playable with a dance pad because everything is controlled with the arrow keys! This alone gives it my 'Best One-Handed Game' award for 2015. A level editor and a seeded All Zones Mode are also included for enthusiasts.  Overall, Crypt of the NecroDancer is a superbly unique experience that is cheap enough that anyone who has played DDR should dust off their dance pad for. While it isn't the deepest rogue-like or the hardest rhythm game, there is enough content included to sink your teeth into for at least a dozen hours.

I consider myself pretty good, and have come to accept that I will never 100% this game. NecroDancer also features a mode to play on a dance pad, as well as local co-op. Despite how there isn’t much reason to replay characters that you’ve already completed, I could see this having great replay value simply for the fun of it.  Story: The Plot is surprisingly enthralling despite most of it being told through ten second cut scenes. It makes your journey actually have purpose and drive, where they could have easily coasted on the gameplay alone. It’s all pretty emotionally charged too. Though with the blend of music and gameplay, it mostly comes off as totally badass. The characters are likable and have some handicaps that really mix up gameplay.  Music:  NecroDancer has not one, but three amazing soundtracks, so any stage you play will have 3 different versions of its music. Add this to the fact that every stage and boss has unique tracks; it piles up to be roughly 70 songs. And honestly, I haven’t found one that I didn’t like. I’ve even danced to the OST while alone in the dark cause I was getting so into it. Thankfully, the Soundtracks are also available on Steam. And if it’s not your thing, you can even import music from your own library. My personal recommendation is to go into options, and set all character soundtracks to random. This way, you will get the most variety out of your experience right away as you’re still learning the game.  Art: As much as I don’t care for the pixel style in general, they do a great job with it. Every character moves smoothly to the rhythm, bending knees, bobbing heads and whatnot. The cut scenes are basically just a moving slideshow with dialogue, but they’re still very nice to look at. Each boss also has a little intro splash screen that I just love.  Tip: If you're having trouble starting, switch to the character named Bard, he is not constrained by the songs rhythm so you can really take your time.  All in all amazing. I would recommend it to anyone, on sale or not.

At that speed, there's no time for reaction, you have to plan out the entire battle ahead of time, which is hard considering that you can't always predict enemy movements. One of a Kind. A Must for Any Gamer Who Likes A Challenge.  Crypt of the Necrodancer is a rhythm roguelike unlike anything else produced to date. It takes a turn based battle system and turns it on its head by having the turns fall on the beat of the game's killer soundtrack. Yours and your enemies' moves fall on beat as you navigate randomly generated dungeons in search of paths deeper and deeper into the crypt.   What makes it great? For starters, the soundtrack. In a rhythm based game, a great soundtrack it crucial to success. Crypt of the Necrodancer hits it out of the park. Danny Baranowsky, composer of the soundtracks of the hit indy games Super Meat Boy and The Binding of Isaac, created what it easily his best work to date for this game. The driving beats keep you immersed in the game for hours and hours.   While it COULD only take you less than an hour to complete the four levels in this game, the Necrodancer will not likely allow this so easily. The game is quite difficult, requiring many attempts to learn the patterns of the enemies and what items will best serve you as you travel deeper into the crypt. But don't let this scare you. The game is easy to pick up and play and you will find yourself unable to put it down as you get better and better at slaying the countless undead jamming out in your way. With three challenging floors and interesting bossfights in each of the four zones, you will feel accomplished and rewarded with every victory. You will have earned it.  With well over 100 hours on record since early access, I can say that you will find plenty to do in this game. With 10 unique playable characters and tons of item unlocks, there is no end to the replayability. Leaderboard and daily quests will keep you logging in frequently to test your skills. Have a dance pad? The game fully supports it. Yes, the controls are simple enough to allow you to easily control the game with a pad. It is the definition of easy to pick up, hard to master. Wish you could Necrodance to your favorite tune? Load it up. The game supports custom tracks using MP3s. Want to create your own level layouts? There is a level editor. There is very little the developers did not include in this game. It is chock full of everything you could ask for.   Whether you are a roguelike veteran or someone new to the genre, Crypt of the Necrodancer is a game worth picking up. It is a refreshing new experience in a video game world that has grown a little stale of new ideas of late.   While you are at it, pick up the soundtrack. It is that good.

Pros: -It's a rougelike, which means permanent death and constantly changing dungeon layouts. This game has tons of replayability because of this. -Lots of unlockables, including items, spells, weapons and even characters that can drastically change how you play the game. -The pixel animations are fantastic- not only do they look expressive and goofy, but they also help the player to know when to attack or dodge. -The combat is incredibly simple to learn, but learning the attack patterns of enemies takes time and concentration. Mix this with managing your health and items as well as forcing the player to stick to the beat, and you have an incredibly tense yet fulfilling gameplay experience. -The game is very difficult, but it is incredibly fair. All of the enemies can be beaten if you learn their patterns or know when to use the right items. Eventually, you end up getting into the zone and become a master dungeoneer. -If an enemy is too confusing for you, there are rooms in which you can practice against all types of monsters, even bosses and mini bosses. -Direct support for modding and even speedrunning. Neat. -Local Co-op? Yes Please! -Three equally awesome soundtracks of varying styles that can all be changed out on the fly? Count me the heck in! -Singing merchants? Woo mama. -You can play it with a DDR pad? BEST GAME EVER  Cons: -Content wise, there isn't a whole lot to this game- there are only 4 zones with three stages and a boss each. However, the randomization completely makes up for this. -While there are a lot of unlockables, I ran out of items to buy after about 8 hours of playing. There is, however, a system where you can trash unlocks, forcing you to get them back again. It essentially lets you play the game all over again if you want. -The controls can sometimes be unresponsive, such as when you are trying to use an item or a spell. These inputs require hitting two keys at the same time, and I often would up missing a beat or getting in the way of enemies because the keys simply wouldn't register. This might be a problem with my computer.  Verdict: This game is incredibly well put-together. It's compelling, challenging, and a heck of a lot of fun. Also, I will be really surprised if you don't get some of the songs from this game stuck in your head.  Score:7.5/10

Crypt of the Necrodancer could have easily been a gimmick. It's not. The rhythm-based mechanics aren't just tacked on to the well-tread genre of roguelikes; they form the core pillar of the game, through which all other aspects are bolstered.   The game truly feels like dancing. The core learning mechanisms are a combination of memorizing the patterns (much like dances) of enemies, predicting what they'll do next, and reacting quickly and gracefully to everything happening around you.  When you pull off a full clear of a room without taking damage or missing a beat, it feels like you've just completed a flawless dance routine. It's exhilerating in a way that roguelikes--often focused primarily on a slow, calculated approach--almost never are.  Oh, and the music is Danny Baranowsky's best work.

A dungeon-crawling rythm game is such a neat idea. It's well-executed too, and an absolute blast to play.   There's some stuff that's odd, like getting multiple attacks in on a beat. My only real complaint with the game is that you don't know how to beat the various monsters until you run into them, and some take a bit of trial and error. This means that you end up getting a certain distance and then dying a lot, and there can be 'learning walls' that are typical of many games.   Finding a new type of monster is kind of like when you encounter a new rules interaction in Hearthstone. You won't quite know what's going to happen, and sometimes it's more intuitive than other times. Some people will like that aspect of exploring because it keeps the game fresh, but I dislike having to start over and progress until I find the same monster that killed me to try again. It's kind of like Dragon's Lair in that sense.   Once you beat a monster, you can practice against it in the lobby, but that's not really helpful because then you already know how to beat it.   Despite that quibble, the game is highly addictive and fun. 8/10 will keep playing.

There are many games which combine very quirky game mechanics or ideas that would not seem to logically fit together, and sadly many of them fail because the ideas, in practice as well as concept, don't work well togehter. However, I am certainly glad that the developers of Crypt of the Necrodancer went for it anyway, because their decision to combine dungeon crawling and rhythm mechanics has created one of the best indie games I've ever played, competing with both the giants such as FTL and The Binding of Isaac and the gems such as Gunpoint and Battleblock Theater.  The concept is simple: It's a dungeon crawler where you must move, attack, cast spells, loot chests, and kick ♥♥♥ to the beat of a wonderful soundtrack composed by Danny Branowsky, composer of the soundtrack to other great games such as The Binding of Isaac, Super Meat Boy, and Desktop Dungeons. As you advance through the increasingly dificult levels, slashing skeletons and slaying slimes, you acquire better and better magical loot with which you must battle the final boss of each floor; one of four randomly selected music-themed bosses (all of whom are walking puns). Once you beat the Necrodancer himself, you unlock new characters to do it all again!  I personally have not tried out the Co-op mode myself, but it also looks very fun.  Overall, it is a great game with beautiful art, amazing music, and just enough difficulty and satisfaction to make it fun game after game.   EDIT: Fair warning: it does get pretty hard toward the end. The difficulty curve is not unbalanced per se, but zone 4 is just very, VERY hard, and the boss fights that follow zone 4 are also very difficult, meaning that they'll kill you quite a lot, meaning that you'll have to start all over from the beginning of the zone. Again, it's not an unfair difficulty curve by any means, but it is extremely challenging. That being said, the challenge adds a wonderful degree of satisfaction to finally slaying the Necrodancer, so if I could redesign the game I wouldn't change a thing.  EDIT: Forget everything I said about the difficulty. Even if you've played hard games, you don't know difficulty until you've tried to beat zone 4 as Aria. To this day I've only ever gotten to the boss fight at the end of the zone once. Dios mio, those devs are EVIL. I can't even imagine trying to play Coda.

Fantastic, brutally hard rhythm combat dungeon crawly RPG. Different characters completely change the way the game is played with their own unique challenges. Want to take your time? Play bard, who is not bound to the rhythm of the music. Want to kill nothing and tickle enemies with your flower power? Dove. Want to be challenged to your absolute limit? Try Coda, who plays at double speed, dies in one hit, dies when picking up gold, dies when missing a single beat, and has an extremely limited item pool.  Success in the game is earned through patience and learning the patterns of each enemy - many enemies brutally punish being mindlessly charged, with a few beats of reckless attacking quickly seeing you dead and furious.  Bosses are fun and challenging, but true strategy is not required for most of them when playing the easier characters, as a good collection of items can see you downing bosses in one bar of music. The story progresses through increasingly difficult characters with the final character being substantially harder than those before. It's a difficulty spike, but by the time you reach it you'll feel a possessed determination to reach the end at all costs, inspired by the previous four hours of relentless beats infecting your mind and demanding you complete the NecroDance of Destiny.  Barrier of entry is moderate - non-gamers or the rhythmically (or physically) impaired may have trouble sticking with the game until it 'clicks' for them. Bard allows everyone to enjoy the puzzley elements of the game and practice for harder characters, and there are practice rooms available for absolutely every enemy type and boss; so those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed red dragons can stop slaughtering you on your otherwise perfect run. Session time is short, with levels being 2-5 minutes in length, three levels a zone with a boss at the end of each.  I planned to make this a two minute silly review, but this game deserved justice.  Charming as F**K, could not recommend more.

A quite unique rhythm based retro random generated dungeon crawler. Seems like a quite peculiar mash up of genres.  In a way you would not expect those particular genres to work with each other but somehow this game pulls it off. It's a very unique compilation. On the outside its a dungeon crawler. You progress through a randomly generated dungeon gathering loot. Once you're dead the only thing you are left off is gold with which you can purchase unlocks, additional crates and items to be found in the dungeon. Any unspent gold goes away and you start from the start. And you start all over on each death with just a bigger chance of getting better things along the way.  The combat hover distinguishes it from the normal rouge like games. As its essentially a rhythm puzzle to be solved. In short - each enemy has a movement pattern in which he moves taking a move in the beat. Its easy to learn and tackle a single enemy but when different ones come at you at the same time fending all of them is quite the challenge. It makes for a very unique and satisfying combat when you pull all the moves in the right way.  The audio layer of this game is just amazing. Even more so as it's integral part of the game. It's worth getting the game for the soundtrack alone. I have no words to better describe it - just amazing. Well worth a listen to.  Graphicly it's nothing special, but nothing bad as well. The pixel aesthetic might not be the best pixel art I've seen but it does the job.  Sadly this will not be one of my favourite games ever. Simply because I'm bad at it. Not a big fan of a rhythm based part of it. Moving only on the beat seams a bit limiting and while the combat is quite enjoyable I was more often failing at it than not. In the end didn't feel interested enough to persevere longer than the first layer of dungeon.  I do however suggest checking it out. This game does perfectly what it sets out to do and its unique enough to surprise you. It will not be a game for everybody.  Great game, just not for me.
